metadata.title: COVID19: Top 7 online interactive simulations, curated. | by Arian Prabowo | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: COVID19: Top 7 online interactive simulations, curated.
metadata.description: Epistemic status: No qualification in epidemiology, nor simulations. Just a casual lover of simulations. That makes me under-qualified and over-opinionated. Note that these simulations are just for…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: chart, which is also known as graph by a layperson

all_paragraphs: Epistemic status: No qualification in epidemiology, nor simulations. Just a casual lover of simulations. That makes me under-qualified and over-opinionated. Note that these simulations are just for edutainment purposes. Not for anything real world like deciding on finance strategy, or public health policy, or anything like that. The real deals are much more complicated than this.

Note from the editors: Towards Data Science is a Medium publication primarily based on the study of data science and machine learning. We are not health professionals or epidemiologists, and the opinions of this article should not be interpreted as professional advice. To learn more about the coronavirus pandemic, you can click here.

There are many ways to model individuals (billiard ball vs pixels), or even whether or not to model individuals in the first place (PDE). So this is going to be grouped by category, in no particular order (actually, from what I think is most intuitive to understand):

Washington Post uses a billiard ball model, where each individual is a perfectly elastic 2D circle that with a constant speed on a straight line, living in a rectangle with perfectly elastic walls. This is a very good time to bring up spherical cow:

Milk production at a dairy farm was low, so the farmer wrote to the local university, asking for help from academia. A multidisciplinary team of professors was assembled, headed by a theoretical physicist, and two weeks of intensive on-site investigation took place. The scholars then returned to the university, notebooks crammed with data, where the task of writing the report was left to the team leader. Shortly thereafter the physicist returned to the farm, saying to the farmer, “I have the solution, but it works only in the case of spherical cows in a vacuum”. http://www.physics.csbsju.edu/stats/WAPP2_cow.html

I’m not making fun of WaPo. The whole idea is that designing simulation is an art. It is too hard to make a perfect simulation of the world. You need to make some assumptions and simplification somewhere, without making it too simple and losing the behaviors that we want to model. And I think that WaPo have made good decisions. (For a more sophisticated billiard ball simulation, albeit non-interactive, check the 3blue1brown in the Honorable Mentions section at the end) https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/world/corona-simulator/

Another billiard ball model by Petrônio Silva and team where they compare 5 different scenarios. This is both less and more interactive at the same time. Less interactive because, to interact with it, you need to understand Python. However, if you do, it is more interactive as you can go crazy with it. I also love the quote at the end of the article, here is the extract:
all models are wrong, but some are useful. (George P. Box)
(For a more sophisticated billiard ball simulation, albeit non-interactive, check the 3blue1brown in the Honorable Mentions section at the end)

Kevin Simler on his blog Melting Asphalt: Outbreak. Instead of modelling people as billiard balls, he models it as a motionless square cell in a grid. Interaction with contagious potential is simulated through simply being a neighbor (sharing sides, not corners). I would call this grid / lattice / cell / pixel / raster / cellular automata / Conway’s Game of Life / finite element method. Most interestingly, even when coming up with a completely different model and assumptions, it reaches similar conclusions with the billiard ball model.

There are a lot of parameters to play with, but not too much. And the whole blog post acts like a tutorial that introduces you the parameters (read: game mechanic) one by one. Here is the link: https://meltingasphalt.com/interactive/outbreak/

Very similar with Melting Asphalt, much less interactive, but with one key difference, hexagonal grid. Although simpler to code, using square grid causes many issues, like how it spreads like a diamond (if you use 4-neighbors) or square (if you use 8-neighbors). In short, hex is better for simulations in general because it is the most circular shape that could tile a space. You can read more about it here and here.

R2D3 is an excellent website. I know them because I teach machine learning and it hosts excellent resources that visualize decision trees and the bias-variance trade-off. So when I saw that they do a COVID-19 simulation, I have to check it out, and I am not disappointed.

This is a more interesting simulation as network are the actual structures that epidemiologist would use, not billiard ball or grid. The official terminology for ‘network’ is called graphs. But this is not referring to a chart, which is also known as graph by a layperson. (If I’m not mistaken, the famous game Plague Inc also uses graph as the underlying model). Here is the link to the article: http://www.r2d3.us/covid-19/

All of the simulations so far can be grouped under Agent-based model, where we simulate the diseases at the level of individual person (read: agent). But that’s not the only way to do things. We could do it at sub-population level. And that is what SIR (Susceptible, Infectious, Recovered) model is trying to do. In SIR, transmission between sub-populations are modeled using differential equations. (To know more about SIR model, check the links to Numberphile in the Honorable Mentions section at the end.)

Note that SIR is a legitimate full blown academic level model. What’s implemented here is a variant of SIR called SEIR (Susceptible, Exposed, Infected, Removed). Here is the link: http://gabgoh.github.io/COVID/index.html

Another implementation SEIR model for 2nd opinion to the above. (To know more about SIR model, check the links to Numberphile in the Honorable Mentions section at the end.) Here is the link: https://alhill.shinyapps.io/COVID19seir/?fbclid=IwAR2aXJT79M2AmZxMdy8jsiEuSC4i7ijU8Av6oB4dmlZIeJ2VQgL7Tt3QGxA
Because I didn’t do an exhaustive research before I wrote this.
Another SIR model thanks to /u/curious-b from reddit for informing me: https://covid19-scenarios.org/
These are related things that are not interactive online models:

As expected, 3b1b made amazing simulations, with new features such as dividing the population into isolated geographic area, city center, and using repelling force to simulate social distancing. Unfortunately, it is not interactive. Anyway, here is the link: https://www.3blue1brown.com/videos-blog/simulating-an-epidemic
This is my wild guess. But I think the famous game Plague Inc uses graph based modelling like the R2D3 mentioned above. https://www.ndemiccreations.com/en/22-plague-inc

Two of the simulations use SIER model, which is based on the SIR model, withe the assumption that the audience are familiar with it. If you are not Numberphile have great videos explaining what the model does and does not capture.

The last 2 models are different in another way. They are trying to use real world numbers. And there are many issues with that. This article is a good summary of why it is hard to make a good estimate of the actual numbers to plug in into those models, as well as a good overview of how complex a model could get. Here is the link https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-its-so-freaking-hard-to-make-a-good-covid-19-model/

Now that you have internalize the dynamic of epidemics, you can have a better appreciations when other people talk about strategies in handling this. A good example of such strategy is this article: https://medium.com/@tomaspueyo/coronavirus-the-hammer-and-the-dance-be9337092b56
Again, with a deeper, more intuitive level understanding, data should make more sense now. Here is a good and detailed analysis of the data: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus
I also tried to put my hand on modelling COVID-19. My previous related posts:
The sources to all images are mentioned in the caption.
Link to each sources are available on respective headings.
Thanks to Phillip Luong for introducing me to SIR model and some of the above links.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
PhD student in Machine Learning, Deep Learning, Graph & Spatiotemporal data. Degree in physics, physiology, teaching. www.arianprabowo.com
